findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide recommends following certain naming conventions to improve code readability and maintainability.

findings.title: RSK - Redundant Storage Keyword
findings.description: The contract uses the `storage` keyword in a view function. The `storage` keyword is used to persist data on the contract's storage. View functions are functions that do not modify the state of the contract and do not perform any actions that cost gas (such as sending a transaction). As a result, the use of the `storage` keyword in view functions is redundant.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases unnecessary gas consumption since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 provide native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: PTAI - Potential Transfer Amount Inconsistency
findings.description: The transfer and transferFrom functions are used to transfer a specified amount of tokens to an address. The fee or tax is an amount that is charged to the sender of an ERC20 token when they transfer the token to another address. According to the specification, the transferred amount could potentially be less than the expected amount.

findings.title: AAO - Accumulated Amount Overflow
findings.description: The contract could lead to an overflow when the total value of a variable exceeds the maximum value that can be stored in that variable's data type.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Local scope variable shadowing occurs when a local variable with the same name as a variable in an outer scope is declared within a function or code block.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured with user-supplied input without proper check for zero values, leading to potential problems and unexpected behavior.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows you to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile your contract code.
